conclusion: Consider effects of air resistance and gravitational force to determine velocity ratio.
Identify forces acting on the basketball.
Gravitational force is F_g = mg.
Air resistance force is F_a = λmg.
Net downward force during descent is F_net,down = mg(1 - λ).
Net upward force during ascent is F_net,up = mg(1 + λ).
Calculate accelerations.
Downward acceleration is a_down = g(1 - λ).
Upward acceleration is a_up = g(1 + λ).
Determine velocity before collision.
Basketball starts from rest and falls from height H.
Using kinematic equation v^2 = u^2 + 2a_downH.
Initial velocity u = 0, so v^2 = 2g(1 - λ)H.
Pre-collision velocity is v_pre = √(2g(1 - λ)H).
Determine velocity after collision.
Basketball rebounds to a maximum height h.
Using kinematic equation for upward motion 0 = u^2 - 2a_uph.
Rearranging gives u^2 = 2g(1 + λ)h.
Post-collision velocity is v_post = √(2g(1 + λ)h).
Calculate ratio of velocities.
Ratio R of post-collision to pre-collision velocity is R = √((1 + λ)h / (1 - λ)H).
Simplify the ratio.
Given 0 < λ < (H - h) / (H + h), expression is valid.
Ratio simplifies to R = √((1 + λ)h / (1 - λ)H).
